tutorial.title: Language Support
tutorial.descriptionContent: Use conditionals to translate a message based on the current language setting

executableContent.instructions:
A major greeting card company wants to provide support for different languages on their website. We'll help them!

Firstly, we need to set the message and the first language.

1. Create a `let` variable named `message` and set it to `""`.
2. Create a `let` variable named `language` and set it to `English`.

Let's start with English.

1. Create an `if` statement that sets the `message` to `"Thank you"` if the `language` is `"English"`.

files.name: script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
The syntax for an `if` statement is :
```javascript
if (condition) {<code block>}
```

executableContent.instructions:
It is always recommended to add a default message.

1. Change the value of `language` to `"Japanese"`. You can do this in the variable initialization, or in a separate statement before the conditional.
2. To set a default message, add an `else` statement that sets `message` to `"We don't support "`, and then join the `language` variable so that the displayed string will look like this:
```JS
We don't support Japanese
```

files.name: script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
An `else` statement has no condition.

You can concatenate strings with variables by coding `string` + variable`

executableContent.instructions:
Let's see what your program is setting `message` to.

1. Display `message` in the console.

files.name: script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Use `console.log` to display anything in the console.

executableContent.instructions:
Let's add support for Spanish.

1. Change the value of `language` to `"Spanish`.
2. Create an `else if` statement right under the `if` block, that runs when the `language` equals `"Spanish"`. Inside the code block, set `message` to `"Gracias"`.

files.name: script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
The syntax for `else if` is similar to that of an `if` statement.

The only difference is, you have to write `else if` instead of `if`.

executableContent.instructions:
Now, let's add support for German. The more, the merrier!

1. Change the value of `language` to `"German"`.
2. Add a second `else if` statement that sets `message` to `"Danke"` when the language is `"German"`.

files.name: script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
The order of `else if` statements do not matter.

Just make sure that they are after the `if` statement and before the `else` statement.

executableContent.instructions:
Now that we've coded the conditional, let's double-check to make sure everything is working correctly.

1. Change the value of `language` to a language of your choice. It can be a language the code supports, or that the code does not support. Observe the result in the console. Do this as many times as you please.
